SP.P: Miss Lawson, my uncle requests that you will not refuse such a trifle, as he offers; it is a thing of no sort of value, indeed, I think of neither use, nor ornament.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Not so despicable, neither, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: However highly you may rate it, sir, there is a degree of politeness in lessening the value of what we bestow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Circumstances vary cases, niece; there are some things we should not depreciate.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: I rate the gift so far above my worth, sir, that nothing shall ever tempt me to accept of it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Bless me, Miss Lawson, you are the very paragon of humility; tho' I confess I think you are right not to be teized with such a disagreeable animal; a thing, that by pretending to imitate human speech, puts one out of humour with the sound of our own voice, as much as a monkey does with our species; I hate parrots, and monkeys.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Yes, but you love fops, and coxcombs, don't you? Let me tell you, madam, your tongue runs before your wit, you don't know what you are abusing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I shou'd be sorry to find fault with any thing you lik'd, sir, but I thought it was merely as a naturalist, that you kept such a number of parrots; I did not think it was for the pleasure of hearing them talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I can tell you, madam, I wou'd rather hear them chatter, than you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: Yet they sometimes cast reflections, mal a propos, as well as my sister, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P:
Pray, ladies, let me draw breath.—Was there ever such a couple of vixens!— (aside to Emily) Don't
mind them, miss, but consider what I have said; I am sure it is intirely for your good I speak. You don't know what a vast collection of pretty things I have, and they shall all be yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Where things are in themselves indifferent, sir, persuasions and temptations may avail; but where our resolutions are founded in reason, nothing can or shou'd alter them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Hush, hush, miss, not a word more upon this subject, I have a great deal of business upon my hands; but pray, miss, do think about it. I'll get you a very fine noesgay to-morrow, I'll pull my paul diack tulip for you; the root cost me twenty pounds, but you shall have it. Sure you won't be cruel to me now! Don't say one word, for I must run, and you shall have the tulip at any rate.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Your servant, ladies, was not that Mr. Bel∣mont that left you? I suppose he has been entertain∣ing you with some of his curiosities?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I think he is himself a greater curiosity, than any in his collection, my lord, but I fancy he has a mind to dispose of them all together, and means to give a bargain of them to Miss Lawson.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: He has done me the honour to offer me abun∣dance of rarities, madam, but I am not disposed to receive favours that I cannot return; therefore his treasures are all safe for me

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: I fancy he loads his gifts with hard con∣ditions, and would persuade you to accept himself along with them. Is it not so, Miss Lawson?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I congratulate you on your conquest, Emily; your eyes can do wonders, it seems, and light up sparks in dying embers.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P:
I rather think, my lord, that Mr. Belmont's flame is of that kind, which dying fires emit, to shew their near extinction; and the faint blaze has, but by
accident, cast it's pale light on me; any other object might have been brighten'd by the same glimmer.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: You wrong my uncle's taste; I have not heard of his proposing to marry any lady these five years. Before that time, he used to be generally in love twice a year, and had his summer and winter passions, which he constantly chang'd with his cloaths for the season.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: I am surpriz'd, my lord, that among such a variety of mistresses, he never found one that wou'd marry him; his person must have been tolerable, when he was young; his family and fortune unex∣ceptionable.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Be assur'd, sister, that was not the case; but by the time he had brought the lady to think favour∣ably of him, he began to discover some imperfection in her. Perhaps her nose was a hair's breadth longer or shorter than it shou'd be, according to the exact rules of proportion; a foot, or a finger, perhaps, disgusted him; on which, he immediately quitted his pursuit, and went in search of another model.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: It is happy the men are not so nice, now-a-days, or we shou'd never be able to fix a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I fancy, Louisa, that must be at all times a difficult matter to accomplish; a fine woman will, doubtless, captivate many, but there is something more than beauty, necessary to preserve her conquest over one.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Why, so they say, my lord; but I pro∣test I can't credit it. It is impossible, I think, for a woman to lose her power, while she retains her beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: A moment's recollection must furnish you with such a number of instances to contradict your assertion, Louisa, that I'm afraid the argument will drop, on your conviction; and I shou'd like vastly to have it carried on.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: O! never fear, we'll keep it up; but I won't admit of odds; 'tis only with my brother I argue.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Well then, I grant, that while beauty lasts, it will always have admirers. But these, Louisa, are but pageants to a conqueror; the triumph must be found at home, in the heartfelt love and esteem of a man of sense and honour.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: True, my lord, but that same beauty, that causes admiration and attention in other men, will necessarily preserve our husband's love.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: By no means, Louisa; possession damps the ardor of desire; merit alone can keep the flame alive, and hinder every wanton gale from blowing it abroad; that, like the vestal fire, must be preserv'd by constant watching.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: By your account, my lord, a married woman has just as bad a life as a vestal, if her whole time is to be spent in keeping one spark alive.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I will allow her task is full as arduous, tho' more pleasing. Men are naturally inconstant; and a husband may sometimes see a woman fairer than his wife; but 'tis her fault, if in the whole circle, he can find one that so well deserves his love; whose temper, manners, conduct, and behaviour, are so much suited to his sentiments; who knows no wish or will, but to please him—these charms, the homeliest woman may acquire; without them, the fairest form that ever struck our eyes, cannot retain one heart.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: Indeed, my lord, we are vastly obliged to you for this excellent lesson; and ought to think our∣selves extremely happy in such a sensible and kind in∣structor.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: You make me so, as I hope that these slight hints I have thrown out, may be of use to you. But why so grave, Miss Lawson? I hope I have not made you melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: I have heard your lordship, with the utmost pleasure, and most sincerely wish, that my whole sex had done so too.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I think tho', we ought not to wish that the other sex had heard his lordship; it wou'd make some of them horridly insolent.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Be assur'd, Louisa, that I have only spoke the general opinion of every rational man. But a truce with the subject; for I flatter myself, you have no need of any other monitor, but your own sense and virtue. Pray, Miss Lawson, do you know a Mr. Freeman?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: No, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: She seems not at all embarrass'd. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: L Loui
SP.P: [aside to Lady Mary] What can he mean?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Is he of your acquaintance, Lady Mary? Or of yours, Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: I am not at all acquainted with him, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: One knows such a number of people, by meeting them in public, that it is impossible to re∣member names; we might, perhaps, have met such a person at Soho, or at Almack's. Sister, shall we go see my aunt? I think some one said she was not well.—Will you come, Miss Lawson?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: I'll wait on your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Stop a moment, Emily, I have but just time to tell you, that your father is arriv'd, and I have seen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Is he in health, my lord? I greatly fear this hasty journey may have injur'd him; that wou'd com∣pleat my wretchedness.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Quiet your fears, he is in perfect health, and has promis'd to give his consent to your marry∣ing Sir Charles Somerville; or, in short, whomever else you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: How happy wou'd this kindness once have made me! now 'tis an aggravation of my sorrow, and comes like a reprieve, when execution's past. Yet still I thank my father; he will not press me then to the detested march he once propos'd. O let me fly to him, my lord, and on these trembling knees receive his blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: You must not think of seeing him this night; to-morrow he'll be here, that's time enough. I flatter myself, that a very little time will serve to clear this mystery.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: O grant it heaven! let my poor heart be eas'd of this sad load, which even imputed guilt can cause, and conscious innocence but ill sustain; then let me yield that heart to undivided, and unceasing sorrow, for my lost Somerville.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Dry up your tears, he may not yet be lost. I now intreat you will, for a little time, be guided by me; I wou'd not have you suffer my sisters to per∣ceive any change in your looks, tho' I hope there will soon be a material one in your situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: I shall endeavour to obey your lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: What am I now to think? that Emily's innocent, I must believe; I took her on a sudden, unprepar'd, and yet she answer'd with such calm in∣difference as common questions usually produce. I'll keep a watchful eye upon Louisa; she was not calm, nor did she answer fairly to the question.—I fear the stain comes nearer than I thought; and yet I cannot think so meanly of my conduct towards her, as to suppose she fears me; why then shou'd she conceal the most important action of her life from her sin∣cerest friend?
SP.L: But men and women both have their capri.
We deal too hardly, when we call it vice.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Young Freeman's lodgings; he is discover'd on a couch, with a book in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.

Q.L: " IS she not more than painting can express,
" Or youthful poets fancy when they love?"

SP.P: 'Tis now near ten; at eleven, I'll make another glo∣rious effort to carry off the prize. Her last words were, "Pray be gone, this instant, tho' you shou'd return."—Dear creature! and shall I not accept thy gentle invitation? I'll quarter her arms on my chariot, as if she were an heiress. Lord, how it will fret the sober family in Lombard-street, who have only a cypher on their coach.
Are my cloaths come?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Yes, please your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Get out my white and silver, prepare every thing to dress, and step to the next coach-maker; I want a chariot and six flying horses, to be got ready in half an hour: tell the fellow, I shall deal with him for an elegant equipage, in a few days. [Exit Ralph.
[Aside.] What brings him here? He is worse than the devil, and comes before the termination of his contract.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: Well, brother, have you seen the lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Why, Jack, I thought you men of busi∣ness were more exact? Do you think I can't hold it 'till Monday, that you call upon me before the three days are out? This wou'd be enough to hurt a man's credit in the city; and why it shou'd not be deem'd a mark of insolvency, at this end of the town, I can't conceive.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P:
As you seem to think a citizen has no ideas but what relate to trade, I shall, upon your own pre∣mises, explain my visit. When we have but a slight
opinion of our debtor, and find him tardy, we think it necessary to observe his motions: but where a man of honour is concerned, tho' we may doubt his power, we don't suspect his principles, and therefore never watch his motions.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Which is, in plain English, to say, you look upon me as a scoundrel.—Votre serviteur, tres humble.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: You have drawn this sarcasm upon yourself, by presuming too hastily to explain my motives for this visit; the irksomness of which gives but a bad idea of your integrity. Those who act fairly, need not fear inspection.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Indeed, brother, you seem to me quite on the qui vive, always in a disposition to quarrel, which is a mighty improper temper of mind to visit a lover in, who shou'd be all tun'd to harmony and joy.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: The mind shou'd be at peace within itself, to feel those charming sensations; they must arise from conscious worth—not even the power of beauty can awake them, in mean, dishonest hearts; I there∣fore shou'd rejoice, that you were capable of feeling their happy influence.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Ay, now you talk something like a bro∣ther, and in return for your good nature, I will ac∣quaint you, that I am this moment preparing to visit my charmer.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: Surely you have been much to blame, to delay so long; this is not a proper time of night, to wait upon a woman of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Not for a tradesmen, I grant you, but we pretty fellows are welcome at all hours.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: Prithee, Harry, lay by the coxcomb, and tho' you don't act, speak at least, like a rational creature; what cou'd prevent your visiting the lady, all this evening; upon the plan I propos'd, and you agreed to?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P:
Why, really, Jack, you are so very impe∣tuous, you won't give a man time to answer your
why's, and your wherefores; but if it will satisfy you, I did wait on the lady, this very evening; and am, by her appointment, to see her again this night. I then hope to prevail on her to step into an hired equipage with me, and for the rest of my life, to drive in my own.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: I don't understand you, sure; is she so ro∣mantically smitten, that she can't wait a few days, 'till her friends and yours have adjusted matters for her honour and security? There can be no doubt, that my father will gladly receive her as his daughter, and make a proper settlement, since she is inclin'd to honour us with her alliance.—She cannot have had time to consult her friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: No, truly, nor ever shall, with my con∣sent. Why, Jack, it is impossible you shou'd be so ignorant as you seem; you'll never be a rich man, that's certain. There are coups de maitres in trade, as well as love; and if a man has not courage to make a push, he will never make a fortune.—Consult her friends, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: I thought, sir, when we parted, you had determined to act like an honest man, and deal upon the square?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Why, faith, Jack, you over-awed me then; but being at present a little more assur'd of success, I laugh at your qualms, because I am sure that, by and by, you will laugh with me; and I shou'd deserve to be eternally laugh'd at, if I were to be preach'd out of such an opportunity of making my fortune; and so, my dear moral merchant, your most obedient, for I have scarce time to dress.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: Incorrigible wretch! were I acquainted with the lady's name, I wou'd this moment alarm her family, and prevent her ruin. (looks at his watch) It is now near the time I am to meet Lord Belmont, upon business at his house; I cannot break my word; but that finished, I will return, and watch every mo∣tion of this worthless brother, whom, if I can, (in spite of all the ties of blood) I will detect.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: What's to be done? A plague on that stupid, money-making brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Upon my word, sir, I don't know what you'll do; they say it is too late to get six horses for a journey, or even a fine chariot, to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Why did not you go sooner?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: Because you ordered me to get your things to dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: 'Tis my own fault; why did I waste my time with that dull fellow? But run, fly, try at the inns, get me even a post-chaise. Do any thing to make dispatch.

I cou'd hang myself for being such a negligent block∣head, to defer a thing of so much consequence, 'till the last moment; if I shou'd lose this night, 'tis ten to one but my evil genius, Jack, may take it into his head to describe me as a fortune-hunter, in to-morrow's news-papers, and put Louisa on her guard against me.
Have you succeeded? Have you got the chaise?

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: No, sir, but I have done much better. As your brother went out, I heard him say he had busi∣ness with Lord Belmont, and older his chariot there.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Business there! and at this late hour!—no matter—he cannot guess my scheme.—He has some plodding accounts to settle in a hurry, perhaps, with his methodical lordship, which may be of use in detaining him from any chance of discovering what is going forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralph.
SP.P: True, sir; now what I propose is this; I'll wait on your honour there, and take James with me, and decoy your brother's servants to the ale-house—treat them with plenty of liquor, while James drives the chariot round the house to the garden-door, and waits ready to whip away, when your honour and the lady come to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Bravo, Ralph.—Fortune seems inclined to befriend me, and my brother shall, at last, be a means of my success, in spite of his mechanical morality.—Follow me.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: Lord Belmont's library. Lord Bel∣mont at a table, with papers before him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I am now ready for my banker. What a pleasure there is in regularity! Yet many men, ra∣ther than take the trouble of settling their accounts, suffer their fortunes to moulder thro' their hands, without enjoyment, and scarce find themselves in possession of an estate before they feel the loss of it. I have a noble surplus now for exigencies; I mean those of others, more than my own. For the man, whose oeconomy is properly regulated, seldom feels the force of that sharp word; and I would treasure up my wealth in acts of liberality.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Mr. Southerne is come again to wait upon your lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Desire him to walk in.
What can provoke him to return at this hour? I hoped he wou'd have allowed both himself and me to rest this night.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Finding myself comfortably refreshed after my pipe and tankard, my lord, and John having in∣formed me that the horses are in good heart, and able to set out to-morrow; I thought it was as good to pay my respects to my brother and sister Belmont, to night, as to lose another day in compliments. There∣fore, if you please, I'll wait on them directly, and take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: It shall be as you please, sir; but I am surprized how you can think of leaving town, 'till you have found your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Why, look'e, my lord, I am an old man, and have no time to lose from the comforts of life. It is uncertain whether ever Emily may be found; and I want to get home to my own dear, who will nourish and cherish me. However, if you think there is any chance of finding my daughter, I don't much care if I stay one day longer.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: That is all I ask, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Well then, my lord, I will bide at your re∣quest, and the horses will be the better for it. And since I don't go out of town in the morning, if it is agreeable, I'll stay and sup with your lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I am sorry, sir, I happen to be engaged, but am certain that Lady Bridget, and Mr. Belmont, will be glad of your company. I will acquaint them you are here, and return immediately to conduct you to them. [aside] I must take care that Emily be not seen.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: What a deal of fuss and ceremony is here? Cou'd not he let me go with him? But as he has no wife, may be he is gone to order something for sup∣per, as I used to do, when I was a widower. Ah! I wish I had continued so still, and then I need not be afraid of any body! My nephew is a wise man, that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I am ready now, sir, to attend you; but must entreat you will not mention Emily's misfortune to my aunt or sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Come then, my lord; and since you desire it, I will not.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lady Bridget, Lady Mary, and Lady Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: I am doubtful whether I shall recollect Mr. Southerne; it is a good many years since I have seen him; and I was, at that aera, extremely young; in my infantine state, as I may say.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord Belmont, and Mr. Southerne.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Your servant, sister; you look purely, faith; not a whit alter'd: my poor first wife was a great deal younger than you, and yet she is gone: but we must all go, one time or other, they say.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: My sisters, sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Good pretty girls, my nieces are; the short∣est of them is something like my wife, when she was her age; do you remember your aunt, young lady?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: No, sir; I don't believe I ever saw her.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Perhaps not.—Well, Sister Biddy, and are you jolly, old girl? You thrive rarely.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: Your phrase is somewhat of the coarsest, Mr. Southerne.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Why, yes, we all grow coarse, as we grow old, to be sure. I do remember when you were al∣most as slender as that young miss there. But where's my brother Belmont, the philosopher, as we us'd to call him? Is he poking after cockle-shells, and old bits of copper, still, my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: My uncle, sir, is true to his former taste—but I suppose they have not acquainted him with your being here; I'll send to let him know it. You'll be so good as to excuse me, sir, as I am engag'd. La∣dies, good night; I leave Mr. Southerne in your charge; pray take care of him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: [aside] He sups abroad; that's lucky.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: What do you say, sister?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Not material.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: Pray, sir, have not you a daughter by my aunt? A very accomplish'd young lady, I have heard my brother say.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Yes, yes, madam, I have a daughter; and she ought to be accomplish'd, as you call it: she has cost me many a fair pound; she was no less than ten years at a boarding-school.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Was not that rather too long, sir, to let a young lady remain out of her father's house? She must have been a perfect stranger to you.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Why, truly, madam, so she was; but Mrs. Southerne said it was for her good; and one must give up a great deal for the sake of one's children, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: I am surpriz'd, Mr. Southerne, you did not think proper to present Miss Southerne's duty to me, nor her respects to these young ladies her cousins; in this you have certainly been deficient, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Why, really, sister, as neither you or they ever set eyes on her, I can't say I thought it of any great consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: Notwithstanding our mutual misfortune in that case, sir, proper decorum shou'd be observed. But I shall not on this occasion enter into any contest of sarcasm, or reciprocation of smartness.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Brother Southerne, I am very glad to see you; how does my niece, and your wife, and all your chil∣dren? Egad, you are a fine old Grecian, and wou'd make a very curious bust; it might pass for an an∣tique; will you sit to Rysbrack for me?

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: As to the latter part of your discourse, Bro∣ther Belmont, I don't thoroughly understand it; but as to my wife and children, they are very well; and I am glad to see you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Pray, Lady Mary, where is Miss Lawson?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: In her chamber, sir; I have not seen her some time.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Ay, ay, I guessed it; some of ye have vexed her. I found her crying to day, ready to break her heart. I suppose this is your doings, Lady Bridget?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: Certainly my poor brother is seized with a delirium, to suppose it possible for me to transgress the laws of urbanity and hospitality in any instance.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Surely, sir, you must mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: No, madam, I do not mistake, I am in my senses; tho' so many teizing contradicting women are enough to put a man beside himself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: Pray, Brother Belmont, who may this same lady be? I don't remember any of your family of that name.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: She is no way allied to us, sir, either by affinity or consanguinity.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: You can't tell but she may.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: You'll pardon me, brother, I do affirm she is not of our family.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Then I do affirm she is, for she lives in the house; and she may be nearer to you than you imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: His senses are quite gone.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Faith, I think so; for he seems to me as if he had some thoughts of marrying.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: No, no, my dear uncle is not quite so mad, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Don't be too sure of that, my lady malapert; I hope I am old enough to take care of myself, with∣out your advice or instruction, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Brid.
SP.P: Don't oppose his insanity, irritation may augment it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: By Hercules Farnese, Lady Bridget, if you don't leave off your tricks, you'll put me in a devilish passion; and you had better be quiet, let me tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: For my part, I don't understand all this; I know not who is mad or sober among ye; I think ye are all at a game of cross purposes, and I wish I was safe in the country again.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Please your ladyship, supper is served.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Is Miss Lawson in the parlour?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: No, sir; she is not well, and desires to be excused.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Oh! now 'tis plain that you have made her sick somehow or other among ye—but I'll go com∣fort her as soon as supper is over.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Emily, with a book in her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Reading's a charming exercise for minds at peace; books can even smooth affliction's furrow'd cheek, or change the source and channel of our tears, from selfish to humane; but when the mind is torn with doubts and fears, while mad contending passions labour in the breast, reason itself must fail to calm their discord; nor can the powers of eloquence or musick attune the soul to peace or harmony.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Emily, I thank you for the condescension you have shewn to my request, unknowing of the cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Your lordship's commands were rather an in∣dulgence, than a force upon my wishes; I therefore claim no merit from obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Your father is at present in this house, which will account to you for your confinement.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: My father in the house! Will you not suffer me to see him, sir? O! let me fly to him, and give a loose to that soft sorrow that overpowers my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: No, Emily; for a little time you have pro∣mis'd to be rul'd; I think you want not sense or vir∣tue to conduct yourself; but as I hope that by to-morrow we shall be able to clear up this dark scene which has perplex'd us, I wish you, for the present, to remain conceal'd: if my scheme shou'd fail, I then will give the reins into your hands, and suffer you to guide them.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: It is an office I do not wish for—by nature and by providence design'd, our helpless sex's strength lies in dependance; and where we are so blest to meet with generous natures, our servitude is empire: to such a state I once aspir'd, but Somerville is gone; how lost my hopes of happiness!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Do not despair, Emily; you may possibly be nearer the completion of your wishes than you imagine; mean while, rest assur'd of every thing, in the power of true friendship, to alleviate your distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: An honest heart, my lord, is always grate∣ful; but when oppress'd with obligations, it may want the power of utterance; I cannot thank you, but I feel your kindness.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: My dear Emily, I am sorry to leave you in this dejected mood; but I have two gentlemen to meet me upon business. I must therefore wish you a good night, and hope to-morrow's sun will dispel those clouds that hang at present on your fame and mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Let the bright radiance of unerring truth shine forth on Emily's every thought and action; and pity, not reproach, will then attend her.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Elder Freeman and a Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I shall let my lord know you are here, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: What an amiable man is Lord Belmont! I think no person so happily unites the man of busi∣ness and the nobleman; nicely exact in all his deal∣ings, yet generous as the most dissipated and extrava∣gant; liberality and oeconomy go hand in hand with him, and mutually support each other.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Your servant, Mr. Freeman; your accounts and mine agree exactly; I have look'd them over, the vouchers are all right: but I fear I have trespass'd upon you, by desiring to see you at an hour which men of business generally do, and always ought to give up to amusement; but my being oblig'd to go into the country so immediately, will, I hope, plead my excuse.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P:
I consider my attendance on your lordship at any hour, as one of the rational pleasures of a man
of business; as your conversation at once entertains and enlarges my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: You are extremely polite, Mr. Freeman, and I shall be glad of every opportunity to cultivate the friendship of a person, whose dealings, as a man, and manners, as a gentleman, I so much esteem. If you can spare a little time from business, I shall be very glad of the pleasure of your company in Wor∣cestershire.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: I am extremely oblig'd to your lordship; but my father now growing infirm, his health requires a recess from trouble and fatigue, and he passes most of the summer in the country; I therefore am confin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: You have a brother tho', whose attendance, I shou'd imagine, might set you free—he is bred to business, I think?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: Yes, my lord; but he is too fine a gen∣tleman to follow it. The air of Lombard-street is too heavy for his constitution; he usually resides at this end of the town, has quitted business, and commenc'd fortune-hunter.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: [aside] As I suspected. I fear then, Mr. Freeman, he will make but a bad exchange; both a man's means and manners shou'd be suited to his situation, before he can possibly make a figure in it.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: Nothing can be truer than your lordship's remark; but reason has no power over dissipated minds, and experience alone can reclaim them: how∣ever, I will try once more to bring him back by ar∣gument.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I heartily wish you success, Mr. Freeman.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: And I your lordship a good night.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Your most obedient, sir.

His brother certainly must be the man—How he cou'd possibly become acquainted with Louisa, I can't con∣ceive; but public places put every person on a level; and at some of these he must have seen her. To-morrow I will find this Freeman, and bring him to a severe account, both for Emily and Louisa.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Discovers Lady Louisa at her toilet, her Maid waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: GIVE me that book, and then you may withdraw; I shall not want you again to-night. [Exit Maid.] What can keep Freeman? does he sleep when his good stars and mine are all awake! It seems as if the god of love himself had interfer'd, and dispos'd of the whole family in such a way as to prevent all interruption.—In short, there never was, nor will be such a charming oppor∣tunity.
O, Mr. Freeman! what cou'd tempt you to such a dangerous act of indiscretion? I shall be totally ruin'd if you shou'd be discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Fear nothing, my angel, I will protect you from all danger; this happy night I shall become your guardian, and all my future life shall be devoted to your service.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: This night, did you say, Mr. Freeman? How is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: If you consent to bless me with your hand, we may escape this moment: I did not hear a creature in the house; they are all retired to rest; then do not lose this lucky crisis, but fly to love and happiness this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: It will be deem'd so rash a step, I fear my brother never will forgive me.—Had we not better ask his consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: [aside] I must parry that stroke.—What are brothers, fathers, mothers, sisters, uncles, or aunts, to love? They might perhaps postpone our happiness for settlements, and such dull stuff; for I can assure your ladyship, there wou'd be no fear of a refusal—the family of Freeman—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I have no doubt but my friends wou'd be extremely pleased with your alliance, sir; and for that reason, wish we had consulted them.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Why, so do I, since you seem now to de∣sire it; but, oh! my charmer, think what I must suffer by the least delay? then let me gently press you to be mine; my chariot's at the garden-door.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I know not how to consent, or to deny.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Dear, lovely angel, do not torture me, nor tear my faithful heart, with doubts and fears; you must, you shall be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: What will the world say of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Say, that you had love, generosity, and spirit, to trust a man of honour: but why will you thus waste the precious minutes?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I find you can persuade me to any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Generous creature! now let us fly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Ha! there's my sister going to her cham∣ber, which overlooks the garden; we must not stir, 'till she is in bed. Step into the next room, as it is possible she may come here.
SP.STAGE: [Exit Y. Freeman. Louisa sits at her toilet reading.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: What are you reading, Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Pope's Homer, sister.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: Then you have no mind to compose your∣self to rest, I perceive; the loftiness of the subject, and elegance of the language, will be apt to rouse your attention, and keep you awake.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I am vastly sleepy, notwithstanding that.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: Then I will not trespass on your repose, tho' I am unaccountably wakeful.—Shall I go with you to your chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: No, sister, I'll go with you to yours.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: Come then, and if you have any good nature, you'll chat to me, while I undress.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P:
Poor Charles!—at last he is gone—what difficulty have I had in persuading him to seek for the
only relief his present situation can admit of—rest.—In some few hours, I hope his passions will be as much rais'd with joy, as they are now depress'd by anxiety; for, as I can have no doubt of Emily's conduct, or his honour, they must yet be happy. [A noise of laughing.] By that sound, I perceive that jolly three∣score are still at their bottle, perhaps they are in the right; age shou'd enjoy, or rather catch each passing moment of delight; youth shou'd husband time, and spend it sparingly; the spirit, not the lees of life, is worth preserving
I hope you have met no accident to bring you back, Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: I scarce have breath to tell you.—Passing again by your garden-door, I saw it stand open, and at a little distance, a chariot: I asked the coachman who he waited for? he said Mr. Freeman; he is this moment, in your house, my lord, upon some clandestine purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: You have amazed me; but let us act with caution, nor trust my servants with my sisters honour—to one of them he comes. O Charles, this is a heavy trial.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: It may not be so bad as you imagine; your own maxim is, to hope the best.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: We are all philosophers, when others suffer, but tremblingly alive to our own feelings. I'll go, this moment, and search every apartment. Do you place yourself upon the center of the stair-case, and lock the folding doors—if the villain shou'd fly from me, you must meet him. But remember, Sir Charles, he is accountable to me this night, to-morrow he may answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P:
Was there ever any creature so teizing, as Lady Mary? I really believe, if I had staid with
her, she wou'd have continued talking 'till morning. It is amazing that she don't go to bed. I dare not let Mr. Freeman out, 'till I think she is asleep. Bless me, what noise is this?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: O Louisa, my brother is this moment running from room to room, and searching every corner with his sword drawn, and a wildness in his countenance, not to be express'd: I am terrified to death.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I am undone! Freeman is in my chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: What shall we do? There may be murder if they meet.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I cannot speak, or think.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mar.
SP.P: Let him fly down the back stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: It must be so, there is no other way.—Do you return to your chamber.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: A passage, with a chamber-door shut.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: The stair-case door is lock'd, there's no retreating. If I cou'd get into any of the rooms on the middle floor, I wou'd leap out of the window, and hazard my neck, rather than bear to be expos'd. I hear Lord Belmont's voice, I'll force this door, at all events.
Ha! what has conjur'd up the only form, that at this moment cou'd encrease my terror?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Is it an apparition that I see! Defend me gra∣cious heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Dear madam, don't be alarmed; upon my knees I beg you will protect me; my life's at stake, and what is dearer still, a lady's honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Inhuman wretch! you have already robb'd me of all that was most precious, my lover and my fame; I have now nothing but my life to lose, and you may take it freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P:
By heaven, madam, I never design'd you the least injury; and if you have the smallest grain
of compassion, you will assist me to escape. I am ab∣solutely ruin'd if you don't, and so is Lady Louisa.—Is there no way to get out?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Thou worse than murderer! do not pro∣fane a lady's name, that I am certain knows you not; but if you have the least compunction for all the sor∣rows you have brought on me, say why you haunt me thus?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord Belmont, Lady Mary, and Lady Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel
SP.P: Now ladies, this affair must be explain'd.—Who are you, sir, that have thus broke into my house, at midnight, and taken refuge in this lady's chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: I'm at my last push; there is but one way. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: This moment speak, who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: A gentleman, my lord, but one, I must confess, who, tempted by strong passion, has infring'd that just respect, which is your lordship's due, by en∣tering your house without your knowledge: but love, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Of whom? declare that, instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: [aside] Now I'm undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Your lordship will, I hope, excuse my mentioning the lady, as she is equally involv'd in this unlucky accident.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: No trifling, sir; explain yourself this mo∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: [aside] Sure 'tis a vision! no, it is my Emily.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Will nothing, sir, avail, to save the lady's honour?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Nothing shall save your life, sir, but a fair confession.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Why then, my lord, I must own, tho' very unwillingly upon my honour, that I came hi∣ther by this lady's appointment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char
SP.P: my fears are true, and I can hold no longer. [comes forward] Ungrateful woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Good heaven! this is too much.
SP.STAGE: [Faints. L. Louisa, and Lady Mary carry her off.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: This is lucky, however. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I am struck dumb with wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: [aside] What the devil has brought him here?—Your lordship sees how much you have dis∣tress'd the lady, by pressing her to own her passion; ladies are apt to be bashful, when there are strangers by.—Perhaps Sir Charles may not know me. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: I beg, my lord, you will inform me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Pray, Somerville, be calm; at a proper time, I shall satisfy all your enquiries about Emily.— [To Freeman.] I have one question more to ask you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: I am ready to answer with the same truth, my lord.—Egad, I shall come off with flying colours. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Were not you in this house about seven this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Why, as a man of honour, my lord, I can't possibly tell a lye; I was here about that time, but the lady was then afraid of being discovered, and desired me to come at this hour, when we concluded the family wou'd be at rest.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I am satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Why then, my lord, I beg leave to wish you, and the ladies, a very good night, and ask a thou∣sand pardons for disturbing your lordship's repose.— [Going]

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: [aside] He has brought me off trium∣phantly, but I must see the event.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: Stay, sir, I have yet something to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Well, sir, pray what are your commands?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: In that light you are to understand them, sir, for they shall be obey'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: You'll please to be as brief as you can, sir, for it grows late.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P:
That I have lov'd that wretched, hapless Emily, I need not now inform you; I have no doubt,
but she has already gratified your vanity, by boasting of the sacrifice she made, however worthless she her∣self might think it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Upon my honour, sir, the lady never men∣tion'd your name to me in her life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: No interruption, nor evasion, sir, they can't avail. Fallen as she is at present, in my esteem, I will still, as far as she has left it possible, preserve her same; you must marry her immediately, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: L Loui.
SP.P: Ha! what can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: You are not in earnest, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: Quite determined.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: You must excuse me, sir—You do me honour.—But I have particular reasons—which, at present, I cannot so well explain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: [draws] Villain, defend yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: [interposes] Not in this house, Sir Charles; I must not suffer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: No place shou'd be a sanctuary for such a monster.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mr. Belmont and Mr. Southerne.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Why, what the devil's the matter here! if you are for a bout of tilting, have with you, I'll be on the weaker side.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: I say, what's the matter? I am a magistrate, and command the peace in the king's name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: [To Free.] We are prevented now; but if you do not chuse to join the name of coward to that of villain, I shall expect to hear from you to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Pray, sir, hear me now.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Why, hey! what the devil is this? Here are the two fellows that ran away with my daughter; they shall give an account of her directly; who knows but they have murder'd her. I command you all to assist me to apprehend them.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Emily, and falls at Mr. Southerne's feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Behold that wretched daughter at your feet, murder'd, indeed, in her lost peace and fame; but still alive to filial tenderness. O Somerville!

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Why, Miss Lawson, what do you kneel to him for? get up, my pretty creature, and come to your own love; don't cry, don't cry.—Just as she stands now, she wou'd make a pretty model for a small Niobe.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: No, don't cry, child, and I'll make one of them, at least, marry you, or I'll hang them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Neither of them shall have her; I'll marry her myself.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: What, marry your niece, brother Belmont? Why don't you know Emily is my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: None of your shams to me, I won't believe a word of it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: [To Freeman.] Have you had leisure, sir, to make your option, whether you will accept this lady for your wife, or vindicate your refusal with your sword?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: What can you mean, my lord, why am I offer'd to that detested wretch? No power on earth shall force me to be his.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: Well acted, madam, but the farce is done.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: You hear, my lord, that the lady abso∣lutely refuses, you would not be so cruel to compel her.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Ay, but I say I will compel her and you too; I'll have no more plague with her: this was the way she serv'd me about Winterbottom; I wish I had made her marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P:
Egad, I begin to think she is his daughter; and if that be the case, she shall get a husband.—Do you hear, you hatchet-face gentleman, that are very like my worst medal of Nero, if you don't marry my niece directly, you shall have a couple of ounces of
lead in your stomach for breakfast, instead of your coffee to-morrow-morning; that is, if she says you promis'd her marriage; but if not, you are at liberty to go about your business.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: I dare appeal, sir, to the lady's truth and honour; if she says I ever promis'd to marry her, I am ready to do so this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Why that's fair enough.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: I say right or wrong, nolens volens, he shall marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Pray, madam, speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Though your inhuman artifices have undone me, I claim no promise from you, and call on hea∣ven to witness, that 'till within this hour I never spoke to you, nor saw your face but once, 'till this unhappy night, in my whole life.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: This is amazing!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: By heaven she does not blush! Sure, ma∣dam, you forget that I stand here. Is it not enough that you are sunk in my esteem? But will you teach me to despise myself, for having ever lov'd a woman that can be capable of such mean, such unavailing falshood?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Sir Charles, I pity more than blame you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: Insolent generosity! But I disclaim your pity; keep it, madam, for yourself, lest you should miss it elsewhere.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Pray, sir, don't scold my niece so; I don't see how she has deserv'd it from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: O Somerville! is it possible you yet can doubt my innocence?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: No, madam, I have no doubts; but beg you'll not profane a term that is your sex's brightest ornament—your innocence!

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P:
Come, gentlemen, all this talk signifies no∣thing; one or other of ye must marry my daughter, that's certain. You have acquitted this gentleman, child; now what have you to say to the other? I can
safely swear he promised to marry you, for he asked my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: If that be the case, I shall discourse him pre∣sently.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Come, don't be afraid to speak, child; I am in a very good humour now; and if you have a mind for that same knight, before George he shall marry you, or I'll hamper him at law, that I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: You are so kind to promise, sir, you will confirm my option.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Ay, that I will, here's my hand for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: And here's mine too, niece (tho' I am sorry to call you so) that no man alive shall use you ill while I am able to draw a trigger, if it was only for sake of that love I had for you, when I had a mind to be nearer related to you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: [To Sir Charles.] I cannot guess where this will end.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: I am all impatience.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Tho' it must call a blush into a virgin's cheek, to own her love, before so many witnesses, yet as it is the only declaration of this kind, that I shall ever make, I will confess, that dearer than my life or fame, I love Sir Charles Somerville,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: Confusion! Belmont, what can she in∣tend?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Pray hear me out, the difficulty's past: I have avowed my love: but were that man, whom my heart owns its lord, to sue with all his former tenderness and passion, to obtain my hand, not worlds shou'd bribe me to bestow it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: [aside] That's very odd, tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P:
While in his heart there cou'd remain a sin∣gle doubt of my truth or honour; and as my injur'd fame is now obscured, all I request, is, that you will permit me to retire to some distant part of the world, where my unhappy story is not known, and where my name may never bring disgrace upon my family;
this, sir, is my sole request, and you have promised me to grant it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: O Belmont, she has torn my heart! but yet conviction cannot lye, my eyes, my ears, are wit∣ness of her falshood.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: By Jupiter Ammon, you sha'n't go into any lonesome place, you shall live with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: [To Emily.] Madam, the kind confession you have made, at least deserves my thanks, and I am truly sorry your conduct shou'd have contradicted it so far, as to make them the sole return I can with honour offer.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: [aside] I begin to feel unhappy about this girl; I cou'd almost recant—but what becomes of Louisa, then?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Had my resentment and resolves left it in your power to have shewn gratitude, in any other way, you never shou'd have known your obligation.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Still more and more mysterious. [To Sir Charles.] I know not what to think; but, let her faults be what they may, she carries her punishment in her own breast, and bears it nobly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: [To L. Belmont.] I am distress'd, beyond all measure; I cannot stand this scene. [To Emily.] Madam, my ardent wishes for your happiness, tho' with as little hopes of their success, as those I may bestow upon my own, shall still be yours—at present, I am sure, I rather increase, than lessen your distress, I therefore take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Adieu, for ever!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lady Louisa, and Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Stay, sir! though I were sure to forfeit as much happiness as Emily deserves to possess, I cou'd not think of saving it at her expence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: [To Lady Louisa.] Speak, madam, quickly speak.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P:
You must allow me time; I have a severe task to go through; and first must own myself un∣worthy
of the most unbounded confidence, that a kind brother ever yet bestowed, or a rash girl abus'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: [aside] Sure the devil won't tempt her to betray herself!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Speak without fear, Louisa, and be assur'd your motives for this generous confession already have excus'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Shou'd even the loss of your esteem, my lord, attend the knowledge of my fault, I cannot bear that innocence shou'd suffer, and therefore will avow it. That gentleman [points to Freeman] came here this night to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: [aside] I shall have my throat cut, that I see plainly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: By your appointment, sister; who did he come to in the afternoon?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: Aye, my lord, what brought him hither, at that time? This is what ladies call a pious fraud of friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Equally inclin'd to clear that lady's cha∣racter, tho' not equally involved in the consequences, I own that I was acquainted with his visit at that time. Your lordship may remember my confusion, when you came up this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Is the man bewitch'd? Did he court all my nieces, and won't marry any of them? I'll fight him with three case of pistols.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: I am in a stound, Brother Belmont; I don't understand all this.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I do remember that you seem'd distress'd, but pray was it to you he came?[To Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: No, my lord, it was tome. Speak, Mr. Freeman, you have often told me your family and fortune might claim me for your wife; are you ashamed of your attachment to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: O, by no means, madam, tho' I may ap∣pear a little aukward at present.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: You see my brother is ready to forgive my folly, in carrying on a match clandestinely, that I might have own'd with honour; but indeed, my lord, it was my own romance, tho' I think Mr. Freeman has acquiesced rather too far.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, ma'am, it was entirely to gratify your ladyship's humour, that I did not at first apply to my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: I have confess'd it, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: But since matters have taken this odd, ri∣diculous turn, I think it will be the best way to let my lawyer wait upon his lordship in the morning with my rent-roll; your ladyship shall have a carte blanche, I assure you, quite the same as if this affair had never happen'd. [Aside.] Egad, I wish I was fairly out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: [aside] Insolent puppy!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: As matters seem now to be upon a proper footing, I think it will not be amiss if I retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: Hold, sir, did not I find you in this lady's closet [points to Emily] one night at Bath? You did not come to Lady Louisa there?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Ha! this I am quite a stranger to!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: [aside] Egad, it is all out now. Why, sir, that this lady and I have met before is most cer∣tain.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Good heaven! can you persist in such inhu∣man falshood?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: O, 'tis quite clear, and this affair of Lady Louisa's is all pretence, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: 'Tis not unlikely, I may be deceiv'd. [To Emily.] You shou'd have own'd your acquaintance with Mr. Freeman sooner, madam, and not suffer'd me to expose myself, by trying to save your character, which is already lost.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Do not insult her, sister; if she is inno∣cent, it is a crime; if guilty, she has load enough to bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My lord, the gentleman who was with you, upon business to night, desires to be admitted to you upon a very particular occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Bid him walk in.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Must my disgrace be made the common to∣pic, and I the public gaze? Let me retire, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: No, Emily, I intreat your stay for a few minutes, perhaps this gentleman may be of use.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: I have no right, my lord, to hope relief from strangers, when love and friendship have abandon'd me. Yet I will stay, if you desire it; for grief like mine is patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: [aside] Nay, then the devil does owe me a spite, and is resolv'd to pay it.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: By the confusion I read in my brother's face, my lord, I begin to think that my presence is unnecessary to his detection. But I beg the honour of speaking a word or two to your lordship apart.
SP.STAGE: [They retire to the side of the scene.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: His brother! 'Tis I that shall become the public topic now.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Hey day! Brother Belmont, what new ad∣venture is going to open on us now?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: [To Lady Mary.] I suppose this gentleman must be your humble servant, Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: I am infinitely indebted to your friendship, sir. Sir Charles, this gentleman has confirmed what Louisa has before confessed. What is your opinion now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: I know not what to think, I am distract∣ed; but still that Bath affair dwells on my mind, and weighs down all my hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P:
Why, then, sir, since Mr. John Freeman has thought proper to expose me before Lady Louisa, and that I have no farther hopes of recovering her
favour, I will, without reserve, ease your mind and my own, by discovering the whole truth.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Do that, sir, and you may find a friend, where you had reason to expect an enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: Ay, do, pray tell us how that same business came about.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Pray, sir, do not keep me longer on the rack.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: I must have time to blush a little before Lady Louisa, madam, as I may possibly appear in her eyes a most unworthy wretch.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: Nothing that you can say, sir, will alter my opinion of you, or remove the contempt I feel for myself; so pray proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Well, madam, [to Emily] the story is but short. You had a very pretty maid at Bath.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: A bold, pert slut; Mrs. Southerne never liked her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: But I did, sir, nor was she in the least cruel; and by her appointment I was passing thro' your chamber into hers, at the very instant that gen∣tleman [points to Sir Charles] and you came into the room. She pushed me into your closet, shut the door, and vanished. The rest you know too well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: How cou'd you, sir, be so inhuman, to let my Emily suffer? O Belmont, I dare not look upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Free.
SP.P: Sir Charles, had your passion suffered you to have asked me then my errand, I shou'd have frankly own'd it; but while I had hopes of Lady Louisa. I could not, with any decency, have reveal∣ed these last particulars. And now, that I have done all in my power to set matters to rights, and atone my faults, I can only, in palliation of my behaviour, say, that it was not badness of heart, but dislike to a se∣dentary life, which tempted me to leave my sphere, and soar at higher objects. In which, I am now sen∣sible, I have justly failed; and must encounter the deserved fate of those, whom vanity seduces from the situation of life provided for them.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Free.
SP.P: The daring to confess we have been wrong, is not only the highest act of bravery, but the best security for our future amendment; and thus re∣claim'd, I am proud to embrace my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: But what is all this to my poor child's cha∣racter, that had like to be ruined by you, and that impudent baggage?

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: O, sir, I am too happy to have my conduct cleared, both to the world and you! And yet, how gladly wou'd I now recall the fond confession, which distraction wrung from my weak, sinking heart, and now o'erwhelms me with blushes and confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Loui.
SP.P: You have no cause to blush; it is for weakness, such as mine, to sink under my own re∣proach.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: You are both too rigid to yourselves; but there is one who well deserves your pity, because he fears to ask it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: I do not, my lord, presume to ask for Emily's forgiveness, nor dare I form a hope that she shou'd grant it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P: Sir Charles, I do not wish to triumph over your humility, but beg you will allow me to indulge my own generosity, by assuring you, that thro' this whole affair I never once condemned, but pitied your mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: My generous Emily!

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Why, what is all this about? If you like my niece, why don't you come and take her, and her pity, and her pardon together, and I'll give you a good five thousand pounds into the bargain. Come, brother, give her hand to Sir Charles, and let's make an end of it.

SP.SPEAKER: South.
SP.P: With all my heart, brother, if they are both willing, for I promised my lord to give my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Bel.
SP.P: Now, Emily, it rests on you alone, to shew that noble minds most easily forgive.

SP.SPEAKER: Emi.
SP.P:
I have been only on the defensive, my lord, during this whole warfare; and such an enemy is ge∣nerally
ready for terms of peace; therefore if you shou'd hold out the olive branch in my name, to your ally, you may suppose I shall accede to the treaty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Char.
SP.P: No words can speak my gratitude; my heart's too full for utterance. Transporting charmer! every way you have conquer'd, subdued me, by esteem, as well as love.

L.HI: From these events, the innocent may know,
That suffering is the lightest part of woe;
While our own conduct vindicates from blame,
Slander defeated, but augments our fame.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.STAGE: Spoken by Miss WILFORD, in the character of Lady LOUISA.

LG.L: I Had an Epilogue to speak to night,
But I'm so hurried, put in such a fright,
Deuce take me!—if I ha'nt forgot it quite.
To see my name in first night's play-bill printed,
A character quite new, in time quite stinted;
An Epilogue, besides, to get by heart,
'Tis most unmerciful, too long a part—
But they so coax'd and wheedled me to duty,
Lest I should fret—for fretting spoils one's beauty,
That, in obedience to the kind command,
A suppliant to your favour, here I stand:
And hope, instead of what had been prepar'd,
Some nonsense of my own, may now be heard.
Well! I have had a great escape, I own,
From being made the jest of all the town;
For from the court end I could claim no pity,
Nor had I more to hope for, from the city;
Such matches rarely answer either side,
For industry is suited ill with pride.
But, to divert your censure, let me shew
A folly more compleat, a city beau!
What contrast can there be so strong in nature,
As English plainness apeing petit-maître!
And yet poor I, by missing such a lover,
May wait, 'till all my dancing days are over!
Next, shift the scene—behold a virtuoso!
An old illiterate, feeble amoroso!
What weakness can the human heart discover,
More shameful, than a climacteric lover?
Men, who have turn'd the period of threescore,
Become mere virtuoso's—in amour.
Nor does Aunt Bridget merit better quarter,
Who, scorning to abide by female charter,
Invades a province, to our sex deny'd,
Aiming at knowledge with a pedant's pride;
When, after all our boast, we find, at length,
To know our weakness is our surest strength,
One path of science only, wise men say,
Is left for female learning—to obey.—
If characters like these your mirth excite,
And furnish some amusement for the night,
If nought offend the maxims of the stage,
Or shock the nicer morals of the age,
If only venial errors here you find,
Critics be dumb—ye men of candour, kind.
